docs.abstract: New study suggests dietary change that may help protect women against both breast cancer and heart disease; researchers find that women who consume monounsaturated fat, main ingredient in olive and canola oils, have lower risk of breast cancer than those who eat other kinds of fat; olive and canola oils have already been recommended as safest sources of fat in 'heart healthy' diet; new study hints that polyunsaturated fat, predominant in corn, safflower and soybean oil, may increase risk of breast cancer; table shows various oils and their amounts of saturated fats, cholesterol, polyunsaturated fat and monounsaturated fat (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICAL research in recent years has offered women some cruel choices. They are told, for instance, that taking estrogen after menopause or having one drink of alcohol a day will reduce the risk of heart disease but increase the risk of breast cancer. A new study provides some relief, by suggesting that one dietary change may help protect against both diseases. Researchers have found that women who consume monounsaturated fat, the main ingredient in olive and canola oils, have a lower risk of breast cancer than those who eat other kinds of fat. Olive and canola oils have already been recommended as the safest sources of fat in a ''heart healthy'' diet.

headline.main: The Nation: Not Quite Seconds for Everyone; The Fat's in the Fire, Again

docs.abstract: Comment on findings of study by University of North Carolina researcher Dr June Stevens, recently published in New England Journal of Medicine, which suggests that excess risk of dying associated with obesity is modest and declines as people age; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE editors of the august New England Journal of Medicine gave their guilt-plagued overweight readers a New Year's gift. Losing weight, they wrote in their Jan. 1 issue, is ''an ill-fated New Year's resolution.'' Their evidence is taken from one of the largest studies ever conducted on the risks of obesity. In the study, which was published in the same issue, researchers analyzed the fates of 324,135 white adults who were followed for 12 years. They found that the excess risk of dying associated with obesity was modest and declined as people age. By age 65, the effect was virtually absent. It disappeared altogether by the time people reached 74.
